awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Applying Machine Learning to Mitigate Disruptions in Novel Relay Trucking Model
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts of this SBIR Phase I project include a more sustainable and profitable trucking industry, enhanced conditions for the trucking workforce, improved public road safety, reduced emissions, and a path to future advancements using alternative energy and autonomous technologies. This project centers on a patented technology that pools shipments and matches tractors and drivers with trailers and cargo in a relay fashion that ensures equipment and cargo keep moving while drivers return home daily. Research has established the theoretical viability of applying relay models in long-haul trucking to solve equipment and human capacity issues. Using relay trucking could potentially double asset utilization, cut delivery times in half, and decrease the high cost of truck driver turnover. To date, no company has created a technology to implement scalable relays in American trucking. Customer discovery and research suggests this is due to the complexity of predicting and mitigating real-world trucking disruption events (e.g. traffic accidents, equipment breakdown etc.). The project aims to assess the feasibility of developing a machine learning (ML) based predictive analytics tool to make our relay technology resilient to disruptions in the driver scheduling and truck route optimization problem. A successful project would extend a relay trucking model beyond largely theoretical studies to build the first real-world application in the U.S. It aligns with NSF’s mission by transforming the trucking industry while creating better jobs for new and existing truckers and reducing carbon emissions. We estimate that resolving the inefficiencies resulting in the loss of $110 billion per year.

This project aims to prove the feasibility of using machine learning (ML) techniques to build a predictive tool that integrates with our relay scheduling algorithms to effectively estimate the likelihood of occurrence of disruption events and provide actionable intelligence for deployment of mitigation strategies. A successful outcome will create resilient relay algorithms necessary to commercialize the first scalable relay trucking operations in the U.S. While the use of ML has been explored in predicting weather and traffic events in the recent past, no off-the-shelf ML tools are known to exist that can be utilized for this patented relay technology. This project leverages real-world proprietary operational data from large trucking companies, combined with public data sources and artificially populated datasets representing drivers and equipment informed by work with local partners at relay nodes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:

This Phase I project, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) program, aimed to achieve proof of concept (POC) for employing machine learning (ML) techniques to predict impact and provide actionable intelligence around potential disruptions in a novel long-haul relay trucking system. Traffic speed changes due to weather or crash incidents (among other disruption events) can create travel time delays, which in turn impact driver and asset location at scheduled relay exchange times. Unmitigated compounding delays can, in turn, negatively impact an entire relay chain. Therefore, a predictive tool that can assess the likelihood of disruption occurrence and quantify impacts on travel time reliability is essential to the realization of the game-changing benefits of scalable full-truckload relay freight trucking. 

Intellectual Merit:

To these ends, Phase I technical objectives comprised: 1) developing and executing a standardized method for data preparation; 2) building and training ML models; 3) testing the level of correction needed using ML models against predefined relay simulation scenarios; and 4) developing the methodology to integrate ML models into a relay software prototype. The study covered the geographic scope of a heavily trafficked U.S. truck lane, with a two-week time period representing each of four calendar seasons. Data included historical roadway network, weather, traffic, and crash incidents, as well as load data provided by two large trucking company partners. A key achievement of Phase I was the validation of the initial ML-based Travel Time Module (TTM) developed in Phase I to predict disruptions and provide actionable intelligence. A final model used weather and traffic data to predict the likelihood of traffic crashes with 93.97% accuracy. The results provided strong evidence that such methodology could play a critical role in the deployment of scalable full-truckload relay trucking, and Phase I will inform the next iteration of the TTM. Phase II will include live data streams and be integrated with the relay scheduling engine and user interface components in preparation for testing of the system in both simulation and live pilot scenarios. Both project phases inform the development of a practical relay software platform, with the goal of reclaiming capacity from existing human and machine assets to create a more efficient, profitable, and sustainable freight trucking system.

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of this project include both economic and societal benefits. The conventional operating model of long-haul freight trucking has created a significant gap in equipment and human capacity threatening the sustainability of the industry. Point-to-point trucking model, coupled with federal Hours of Service regulations, causes equipment and cargo to spend more than half the shipping time idling roadside, costing carriers $3+ billion a year in fuel and equipment maintenance. The same constraints cause truck drivers to spend a significant amount of unpaid time on the road, creating a mentally and physically exhausting profession with limited monetary reward. As demand for trucking is expected to grow 36% between 2020 and 2031, we estimate that resolving the systemic operational inefficiencies in long-haul trucking will open up a Serviceable Addressable Market (SAM) of $600 million. 

The proposed relay model has the potential to double asset utilization, cut delivery times by 20-50%, and decrease the high cost of truck driver turnover. By transforming truck driving into a localized day job, relay trucking will improve working conditions for drivers and make the industry more attractive and accessible to a larger workforce--addressing the industry’s driver retention and shortage crisis. Additionally, this model could cultivate a more sustainable environment by reducing emissions from idling trucks and empty backhauls (48 to 64 tons of carbon based emissions per truck annually), and build a pathway to large-scale deployment of alternative fuel sources in long-haul trucking. When validated, the resulting software product will disrupt the conventional method of long-haul trucking, eliminating unnecessary downtime built into supply chains.


Last Modified: 10/03/2024
Modified by: Aayush Thakur
